docs.snippet: A growing number of air travelers have found themselves trapped on a blacklist - one kept by an airline....
docs.lead_paragraph: Mark Adkins thought that he was doing America West Airlines a favor by giving up his seat on an overbooked flight from Tucson to Las Vegas. But he says the airline returned the favor a few hours later by banishing him for life. In exchange for surrendering his seat, Mr. Adkins had been offered a free ticket and an upgrade to first class on a later flight. ''But right before the doors closed on the next flight,'' Mr. Adkins, a university research director, recalled, ''a customer service agent boarded the plane and told me I needed to get off because I had been upgraded illegally. I told her my story, but she said she didn't want to hear it and if I did not get off the plane, she was going to call the police.''
docs.abstract: Growing number of air travelers have found themselves trapped on blacklist kept by airline; most commercial carriers maintain small but, by some accounts, growing list of passengers they refuse to transport; reasons for being blacklisted can include disorderly conduct, refusal to comply with crew member's instructions or abusive behavior toward airline employee; drawing (M)

headline.main: Airlines Blacklist Fliers, Some Merely Annoying
English Channel Tunnel Work Facing Setbacks

docs.snippet: In an office cubicle at the U.N. refugee agency, a Syrian woman and her three daughters took turns staring into a camera for iris scans. Their biometric registration, a first step toward possible resettlement in the West, is to be followed by inte...
docs.lead_paragraph: In an office cubicle at the U.N. refugee agency, a Syrian woman and her three daughters took turns staring into a camera for iris scans. Their biometric registration, a first step toward possible resettlement in the West, is to be followed by interviews and background checks that can take months or even years.

headline.main: UN Defends Refugee Vetting as Trump Mulls Revised Entry Ban

docs.snippet: The western German city of Cologne said it had placed a travel ban on the Islamist militant Metin Kaplan just days after a court rejected a Turkish bid to have him extradited to face treason charges. The Cologne authorities said Mr. Kaplan must re...
docs.lead_paragraph: The western German city of Cologne said it had placed a travel ban on the Islamist militant Metin Kaplan just days after a court rejected a Turkish bid to have him extradited to face treason charges. The Cologne authorities said Mr. Kaplan must report each week to the local police and may not leave the city. Turkey accuses him of orchestrating a foiled plot in 1998 to crash an aircraft laden with explosives into the mausoleum of Kemal Ataturk, founder of the modern secular Turkish state. A Düsseldorf court on Tuesday rejected Turkey's request to have Mr. Kaplan extradited, but the German government has said it would try to expel him on different grounds. The court said it had refused Turkey's extradition request and ordered Mr. Kaplan to be freed from detention. He had been held pending a decision on extradition since completing a four-year jail term for calling for the murder of a rival religious leader.
docs.abstract: Cologne, Germany, places travel ban on Islamic militant Metin Kaplan after Dusseldorf court rejects Turkish bid to have him extradited to face treason charges in connection with 1998 plot (S)

docs.snippet: The State Department is recommending that American citizens defer all non-essential travel to Honduras following the military ousting of President Manuel Zelaya....
docs.lead_paragraph: The State Department issued a travel alert on Monday recommending that American citizens defer all non-essential travel to Honduras following the military ousting of President Manuel Zelaya in a coup on Sunday.
docs.abstract: The State Department is recommending that American citizens defer all non-essential travel to Honduras following the military ousting of President Manuel Zelaya.
